author: SteveL-MSFT
body:
Separate fixes for the header and the data rows.  If it's the last column, don't add trailing padding.

Also fixed some Format-Table tests that were `Pending` but the issue was closed.

One side-effect is that using `out-file -width` you don't get the padding on the right most column which seems fine as the parameter is for limiting the width rather than ensuring the width.  But it is a breaking change.

Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5532

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I think we should be more flexible - while we trim trailing whitespaces by default the `out-file -width` (and maybe `Format-Table -Width`) should be padding.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: I'll bring this up at the Committee meeting today.  I think it depends on what `-width` means.  Does it mean exact width or max width.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
@PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this and `-width` should be maximum width only.  This is consistently with behavior today such as:

```powershell
"hello" | out-file -width 100 -path .\hello.txt
```
Also, formatting has not been guaranteed to be a specific format, so this is not a breaking change.

title: Don't add trailing spaces to last column when using Format-Table
